events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--006a51241073e994b41acfe9ec718e94-->
### Code Coverage
For detailed information about the code coverage, see the [test coverage report](https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/30502).
<!--021abf342d371248e50ceaed478a90ca-->
### Reviews
See [the guideline](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-review) for information on the review process.
A summary of reviews will appear here.

verification.payload:
tree 2ffc3665b3ee842144f4717b34d23369e7afe333
parent 8754d055c65e11fd2afa59f9e5de7c60a9e0ec23
author Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1721727880 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1721734298 +0200

doc: add release notes for #22729

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+Notable changes
+===============
+
+P2P and network changes
+-----------------------
+
+- Previously, if Bitcoin Core would be listening for P2P connections, then
comments.body:
```suggestion
- Previously, if Bitcoin Core were listening for P2P connections, then
```

grammar nit.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+Notable changes
+===============
+
+P2P and network changes
+-----------------------
+
+- Previously, if Bitcoin Core would be listening for P2P connections, then
+  it would always bind on `127.0.0.1:8334` to listen for incoming Tor
+  connections. It was not possible to switch off this even if the node didn't
comments.body:
```suggestion
  connections. It was not possible to switch this off even if the node didn't
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+Notable changes
+===============
+
+P2P and network changes
+-----------------------
+
+- Previously, if Bitcoin Core would be listening for P2P connections, then
+  it would always bind on `127.0.0.1:8334` to listen for incoming Tor
+  connections. It was not possible to switch off this even if the node didn't
+  use Tor. For example, a configuration `bind=addr:port` would result in
comments.body:
```suggestion
  use Tor. Previously, a configuration `bind=addr:port` would result in
```

Is this an example? If yes, it would be good to list all breaking changes, instead of only one.

@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+Notable changes
+===============
+
+P2P and network changes
+-----------------------
+
+- Previously, if Bitcoin Core would be listening for P2P connections, then
+  it would always bind on `127.0.0.1:8334` to listen for incoming Tor
+  connections. It was not possible to switch off this even if the node didn't
+  use Tor. For example, a configuration `bind=addr:port` would result in
comments.body: Applied the `s/For example/Previously/` change. Initially I wrote "for example `1.2.3.4:8333`" but changed it to "for example `addr:port`", now this covers all is not an example anymore.
